author: BatMeckley
content: I would say it’s not one or the other. Like, I might do some big timing moves first, just to have the vocal 80% of the way there. I’m talking actually nudging things around, not stretching. Then I’ll consolidate and drop into Melodyne. In Melodyne I’ll turn the whole thing and also really pay attention to the timing. At this stage it’s a lot more stretching and/or compressing notes, or more importantly PARTS of words. Like I’ll separate the consonant, and time compress that and bring up the volume so ccchhhhhhhhair becomes CHaaaaiiirrrr. (If that makes any sense). Then back into ProTools. Double check for any weirdness, comp back in the untuned bits you can get away with if you want. Then I’ll do a final cleaning up of group Esses, do my little what I call Swedish time stretching technique, REALLY pocket and polish the vocals. Then I send it off to the label who needed it yesterday but somehow don’t get back to me for 6 months.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Cian's advice is good. It's hard to know where to start, so I'll just share three "a-ha!" moments that I've had over the years where the reverb sound that I had been chasing was unlocked. Some of these may already be obvious to you:

1. **Pre-Delay Time:** The longer your pre-delay time is the farther away the "back wall" of your mix will sound. 120ms pre-delays (which are huge) will give you that Bruce Swedien depth. The longer your pre-delay the less wet the verb will need to be. 

A short pre-delay time will "glue" the verb to your dry signal, while pre-delays longer than 50ms will "detach" from the dry sound and give you a greater sense of depth *and* clarity.

Experiment with pre-delay times of 20 ms, 50ms, 80ms, and 120ms and see what happens. As you try these settings re-balance your verb with the dry/wet knob and see how that changes the feelings of depth, rhythm, and clarity in your mixes.

2. **Panning/Width/Band-Limiting:** Most verbs default to full-width. Recognize that most verbs don't need to be this massive and practice narrowing your tails. The more that you narrow a reverb towards the center the more it will feel like it's extending into infinity towards the vanishing point of your mix.

Additionally, don't be afraid to focus your verb by rolling off the high-end and the low-end. Verbs contribute to a lot of clutter in a mix.

3. **Slap Echo:** This was a big one for me. The reverb sound that I was hearing on so many of my favorite records (Bowie, Prince, etc) was really just a single band-limited echo blended to taste. Slap echoes tend to live in the 50ms - 100ms delay range. Sometimes that's all that's needed for the feeling of ambience I'm seeking and it takes up *way* less space in a mix.

Once you master that you can start blending your slap echo with your reverb tails and the combination will give you a very expansive sound with minimal fuss.

Think Andrew Watt handled the vocals on that and did a fantastic job getting the take out of Luke. Dance Hall Days by Wang Chung is always a good reference. Mercy Street by Peter Gabriel (the whole SO record) pretty unfuckwithable. Bang Bang is always a great reference because you can really show a singer the difference between a Jessie J and an Arianna. Comes in handy in sessions a lot.

author: popaganda.
content: I’ve been deep-diving on Daniel Johns this last week and really been thinking about the toll that being creative can take on people. It came up yesterday in the VC too. In some ways our culture likes to reward artists being martyrs, but it’s never something to strive for. I think as producers one of the biggest parts of our job is to be a grounding presence and a support for artists who can sometimes have pretty wild swings. But we’re artists too in our own right with our own bipolar tendencies. In a way that can create an empathy bond between us…we can understand the manic exuberance of making an amazing thing and how there’s usually a pendulum swing in the other direction to compensate. But I kind of think our job as producers is to have our shit together enough to buffer that bipolar thing and make a sanctuary where an artist can feel at home. Just my random thought for the day.

author: BatMeckley
content: I mostly fuck with retune speed; adjusting it slows down how hard the tune snaps to the note and it can basically reduce the “severity” of the effect. Classic mode is because when they went from 5 to 7 we all threw a fit because they fucked heavily with the “sound” of the plug in. In an effort to increase transparency they actually messed with the high end artifacts we actually dug, and were using the plugin for (on a lot of the Luke records I worked on we were using melodyne for tune and AutoTune for tone). I clearly remember sitting on the phone with Antares brass for HOURS while they tried to convince us the new version was “better” and me having to explain to them that it wasn’t and we were now traveling with rigs that had the old version because the new version just didn’t have the sound we needed. They compromised by introducing “classic” mode which was their attempt to get the sound of v5 back.

author: Slow Hand
content:
So obviously starting with the right bass is going to get you 70% of the way there, but you know what *really* surprised the hell out of me? The *strings*. 

If you're not getting anywhere close to the tone that you want, start exploring the wide world of bass strings. I had overlooked this simple thing for ages. I took my choice of strings for granted because I never had to change them. And when I did it made all of the difference in my tone.

I've always been a Fender guy: P-basses and J-Basses, and the DI signal was always voiced way too dark to pop out of a mix without some heavy lifting. Granted I also use flatwounds (which aren't as zippy as roundwounds). 

After some research on the TalkBass forum, I ordered a few different sets of flats to experiment. One such set were the *Thomastik-Infeld Jazz Flats*, and ho-lee *shit*. There it was. There was the sound I was looking for.

They were voiced way lighter in the bass, which gave me a far more articulate midrange. Like the sound of an upright bass which (trust me) is a very good quality to have unless you're going for a grindy metal tone. As it turns out, the midrange is where *all* of the action is in the bass. It's okay if your bass DI is voiced with no low-end, because you can always add that weight back in, but if the midrange is not present to begin with it is an uphill battle to make it articulate in a mix.

author: BatMeckley
content:
<deep breath>
So, grasshopper, everything matters, and nothing matters. It depends on where you are and where you’re going, and most importantly actually knowing where you’re going.

I view the difference in shitty gear vs good gear as compound interest. A vintech one on one might sound basically like a vintage neve. ALMOST indistinguishable. But if you’re using it on all 149 of the tracks you’re compiling into a pop song, the end result is going to be 149 times more noticeable. The second floor of the leaning tower of Pisa looks pretty spot on but the people on the 15th floor are freaking out. 

That said, I could record a garbage singer through my 251 and my chain, and if I didn’t know what to do with it, it would still be garbage. The flip side is we actually demoed different mics and different chains on Paris Hilton. There was a right answer. And she’s not gonna win any singing contests, but at the end of the day the cumulative effect of all the decisions we made led to tracks that are still being played in clubs to make people dance over a decade later.

Details matter in not just what the audience hears eventually, but what the artist hears initially, giving them the confidence and headspace to sprinkle in their extra few (sometime more than a few) percentage points of vibe that the audience attaches too later. Fix it in the mix is an abused concept because it doesn’t take in to account the affect of shitty sound or feel on the performance. You think 1 mic doesn’t matter? I’ve heard people sing noticeably more in tune and in time when switching from DAW monitoring to direct monitoring. It ALL matters.

But if you don’t understand songs, melody, rhythm, and how these things interact to move people? None of it matters.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Sometimes for deadline work,  I use a "trust the numbers" or "trust the process mentality" and avoid the time sink of artistic minutia viewpoints.   Meaning...   don't be too precious about it. You know what levels "need" to be.  You know the approximate balance of things. Get it into the range of "that works well enough" and ship it....  Because you HAVE too.  Clients that are pushing against the deadline are (often) just making products, and that doesn't get the same creative refinement as real art. Truth...   some clients often can't even tell the difference in that last 10% of quality improvement anyway (advertising, corporate, broadcast).  Not that you shouldn't always strive to do your best...  but at some point your craft-skill at 80% of max is all they have budgeted for and all you have time to invest and is AMAZING in their eyes.  That's just how WORK is sometimes. Ship it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Granted, her examples are *very* specific to orchestra and not directly applicable to pop records, but the underlying principles here include:

**1) **Think of instrument combinations as a single composite voice.

One instrument can function as the "sustain" portion of the sound and a second instrument gives the "attack". Together they create a single melodic voice.

**2) **How do the instruments stack on each other? Do they clash? Cellos doubling a bass an octave up extend it's timbre into a higher register to make it read better. It's not so different from adding fuzz to an 808 so that it has more presence.

**3) **Which instrument will cut through the music?

---

A few concepts that I'll add:

**4) **Instruments in the foreground vs. the background. Know which part is the lead (focal point) at any given point in the record and then pare down the presence of the rest and push it into the back of the sound stage.

**5)** (Piggybacking off of Felix's excellent post) What is the simplest way to achieve the desired effect? Reduce. Reduce. Reduce.

Cut instruments and parts ruthlessly and approach it with a minimalist's eye. Like writing a haiku: How few elements can you use to create an impression? Maybe a guitar part is carrying 90% of the groove and the drums only need to be a kick and a snare. Or maybe the guitar is covering the backbeat too, and you don't even need a snare!

Constantly ask yourself "What is the most important sensation in the record?" and then focus it by cutting out everything that gets in the way.

**6)** Hocketing. Pass the melody off between different instruments at different points in the song. Play it in different registers. Combine voices occasionally for special effect.

**7)** Tonal contrast. Dark instruments plus bright instruments. Distorted and clean together. Near vs. distant.

Elements that sound same-y will gel together and elements that contrast tonally will pop.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I couldn't speak to the current state of samplers, but I've always wished that someone would build a bold sampler that wasn't afraid to be really wacky and full of unique characteristics. For starters:

1. Include a radio tuner. 
2. Maybe some really nice - but heavily colored - preamps.
3. Include all kinds of weird peripheral sensors like devices that pick up EMF signals or a few contact mics. Include a suite of effect plugins that are specially geared towards these input methods.
4. Super-intuitive resampling, time-stretching, and pitch-shifting features.
5. An algorithm that analyzes the dominant pitch of a loop and auto-maps it to a keyboard. It should be capable of re-orienting itself as the dominant pitch of a loop is adjusted.
6. Tracker-style sequencing capabilities.
7. An OTT-style compressor. Maybe something really trashy and blown-out like Devil-Loc or Vulf Compressor. Something that really messes with the proportions of a sample.
8. Easy and flexible integration of feedback loops.
9. Intuitive integration of polyrhythmic looping or sequencing.
10. A feature for easy implementation of Steve Reich 'It's Gonna Rain' style tape loop phasing.
11. Auto-bpm detection keyed off of designated inputs (ala Ableton).
12. Automated master tempo effects.

I could go on.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
To go further on what @Maxim said: when you stack a bunch of vocals that are all hard tuned, they're gonna phase cancel. I often detune L/R doubles of a lead by a few 10ths of a cycle (like take the left channel to 439.4hz and the right channel to 440.6hz in auto tune) to help separate them.

This is actually what a "chorus" effect is meant to do. When you actually get a bunch of great singers together to sing the same thing, their different timbres and slightly different pitches will add up to a very rich sound you can't get from stacking one tuned voice. That's what the effect called "chorus" is essentially trying to mimic with slight detune and delay.

Not sure if this is a topic we've covered much but I know @BatMeckley and @Slow Hand have thoughts

author: Slow Hand
content:
At the risk of stating the obvious, transitions can also be telegraphed through the instrumental writing too. Whether it's a drum fill, or a chord voicing that walks up/down into the next section, or tension in the melodic voices, or shortening the notes lengths (staccato, staccatissimo).

There's also idiomatic noises from the instruments. Guitars have string scrapes, headstock rakes, that cool chattering thing from tapping near the bridge with the edge of your pick. Pianos have big glisses, horns can squeal, bowed strings can sweep a fast legato scale up into the downbeat or do a large gliss.

Then there's foley. I get a *lot* of mileage from sound libraries made for film audio. Foley artists are some creative people and you can go far layering their sounds into instruments at the transitions.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I used to feel deflated when I discovered that records I loved were sampled or interpolated from pre-existing records; not written solely by the artist that I admired. Still do sometimes.

Another thing happened, though. It shortened the distance in my mind between my work and the achievements of these artists. Doing what they did no longer felt quite so far out of reach. It's not to say that I went out and started sampling records, but it gave me a deeper appreciation for the creative act and assured me that so much brilliance is rarely created in isolation. It's all building on the foundations of what others have done before.

It opened my eyes to having a dialogue between myself and the rich history of music. Music is plastic, malleable, and fluid. There's a hundred and more ways to make something wonderful and they're all equally valid if we don't let our sense of pride prevent us from savoring them.

author: LAPhill
content:
Not a dumb question. The distortion on power chords creates an octave below the fundamental pitch, which helps make them feel well, powerful. For intervals other than a 5th, it's not an octave below but some other pitch, and so yeah, you're likely creating unpleasant harmonics outside of the key.

The dumbest, but easiest way to avoid that is to let the bass be the inversion's lowest note while the plays a 5th from the root note. Otherwise, you're looking at dialing back the distortion on those inversions, or on the tone as a whole, which isn't necessarily what's desired.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
The method that sounds most transparent is hand editing (no digital stretching at all). You need to line up your edits so the wave form is perfect in the middle of each note, then use an equal gain cross fade at the edit point. This gives you the most transparency because there is no algorithmic stretching happening. 

It limits very slightly your options with timing because bass wave forms are long, so lining them up perfectly means you can only move the timing the length of each waveform. It's also time consuming compared to stretching.

If you are editing a DI that is then going through significant processing (amp sims and shit), you can sometimes get away with one of the stretching algorithms. Elastic audio is ok and usable sometimes, but I prefer Ableton's complex mode over everything else I've heard.

I try to avoid time stretching artifacts on lead vocals and bass instruments more than anything else (unless it's creatively interesting of course).

author: BatMeckley
content: Kind of? I can stretch notes absurdly far by just highlighting a single cycle the wave form ( at zero crossings ) duplicating the cycle between one and four times, and then stretching back out the end of that last region, effectively lengthening the word. If it needs more, I move over a few cycles and then do it again, rinse and repeat until it’s where I want. Shortening the words a bit trickier, I won’t take out more than one cycle at a time.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Copying your favorite songs is actually a great way to learn! I've done it a lot and continue to do it periodically, even after making records for like 25 years. 

Think of this like practice, not as how to make *your* music. Trying to make a note for note, sound for sound copy of a song you like forces you to make moves and choose sounds you otherwise wouldn't choose.

By practicing in this way, you accumulate skills that become part of your subconscious creative arsenal.

Again, at this early point in your journey, there really are no right and wrong ways to make things. The key is to just make as much stuff as you can, trying as many different methods as possible.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I mean, at the risk of over simplifying what it is we do, just listen. If you’re getting too much consonant already, I certainly don’t recommend over hyping the consonant any further. 😂

It’s like “how do you know when to use the maag eq to boost the high?” Answer: when it doesn’t sound bright enough. 

The other night I was at a table full of very very very good producers and mixers, and a discussion on the merits of Serban broke out, and there was talk about compression and limiting and making something sound like it comes out of fm radio already and how that effects the human nervous system and… and i was just like, I dunno man, I always thought that we went to Serban because he made sure you could understand the words. Lol. I think a lot of times as producers we can very quickly lose the forrest from the trees and fixate on the upper harmonic character of spectre at a certain oversampling level and it’s like yeah, but man, your song doesn’t have a bridge and the melody is forgettable. It’s like the people that put $10,000 spinner rims on a $700 ‘88 Nissan Maxima. Worry about the color and consistency of the icing once you’ve baked a kickass cake, not before. 

(I also know you’re not the target market for this advice cause you’re already killing it, this is more for the people reading through the discord.)

author: Slow Hand
content:
Wow. I'm making my way slowly through this Lanois/Beato interview and am amazed by what Lanois is describing from @ 52:24 to 53:45 regarding his approach to stacking modulations and special effects.

As he describes it, he's performing and printing his modulation effects (delay, verb, vibrato, pitch shifting, etc) one generation at a time as he iterates through the song. This allows him to fine-tune and perform the modulations on each successive pass so that every moment is honed and responsive enough that it becomes a part within the music, and not just a blanket effects chain.

So if he's doing pitch-shifted delays, he'll do a pass that goes up a fifth on certain notes and then layer another pass that modulates by a different interval at a select moment instead of leaving everything on throughout the entire section. He's honing each effect in sequence. It shows a tremendous care and sensitivity to the music that he would go through and *perform* each layer with so much intention.

This feels like a revelation to me and I can't wait to practice this.

(I've cued up the video where they start talking about it)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vxP9kKzbCFA&t=3144s

author: Skyler Young
content: I was recording on an album and I heard a few tracks that a different bass player played on at the beginning of the session and the tone on his bass part was amazing so I asked the producer how he treated the bass to get that sound and he said he did nothing, it going through the same chain I was. And I was horrified cause my bass was sounding nowhere near as good and I knew the other player had the same type of bass. The only thing that could effect the sound was the tone knob and as soon as I moved it to around halfway it perfectly fit in the mix and sounded as good as the other bass player - has been the biggest key to getting a good sound in the studio

author: chris_donlin
content: Today I said something very simple and honestly think it solved most of the issue. We were getting some scratch vocals down and I suggested we use that as the scratch vocal time to experiment with how we want to capture it. I tend to overlook the importance of a good, intentional scratch, because you might get usable stuff. But then they can sit with it and tweak if need be. I think it’s fair to take responsibility for not pushing him harder for a more intentional scratch. It made the rest of our writing session today go much smoother and just more exciting. Appreciate everyone’s input. In good spirits!

author: samvalentine
content:
@BatMeckley nailed retune and classic... Flex tune allows you to hit notes that aren't allowed in the key; higher the value, more time you're allowed on that note before it'll snap you to a note in the key. I'll keep it pretty low usually but it all depends on the vocalist. I've never really fucked with natural vibrato. Humanize is nice. Let's longer sustained notes wobble a bit even at high retune speeds. Sometimes I'll really crank it, but it does take away from the autotune effect if that's what you're going for.
One other tip is I like to flip to advanced mode and set major/minor in the bottom section (leave top drop down in chromatic). This allows you to bypass or allow certain notes that aren't in the key. So if you wanna hit that flat seven now and then, bingo

author: gatewoodsensei
content:
Absolutely. I went from FL to Ableton and Logic (before Ableton got comping), then played with Bitwig, Cubase and a bunch of other DAWs and S1 by far is the most comprehensive. It’s like the developers sat back and said “I see what they’re doing but what if we made it more streamlined.” Not to turn this into the daw thread, but I’ll give you an example. In order to create a reverse reverb effect, I’d have to cut the part that i want to reverse, duplicate the track in a way that only copies the plugins, drag the cut audio down to the new track, add a reverb, reverse the audio, bounce in place, reverse again, and line it up. 

In studio one, I can create a custom macro that adds all of those commands to one command in sequence and turn that one command into a button. Effectively turning what, like 8 steps, into one. And it does it in seconds.

author: sukhuno
content: So basically what i did was i set up an ableton multisampler with all of my favourite linn drum sounds + some others that i liked (did this for snares and kicks) - so about 127 each. then i made 4 versions of that in an instrument rack and split them using multiband to only certain freq ranges (low, low mid, mid, high) - i think i used shaperbox for this. then i used an ableton random midi effect so it would trigger random samples in each of the 4 instrument racks... so you create a new sound from the seed sounds you choose. you get sounds that are in the linn drum ballpark but just a little different - which is the cool thing. https://we.tl/t-MxppdXPQlf here are some of the ones i liked (kicks, pitched snare, snares) that i made using this method

author: Slow Hand
content: Yeah. I can certainly see that. I think a negative side effect of this contemporary value of "struggle/grit" that you describe is that we've ended up with a whole lot of contrived-sounding performances where the singer is belting or breaking up or singing with a feigned intensity. It's so common these days for songs to be maxed out with a nacho-cheese level of intensity. The emotional affect is turned up to a ten. Everything is maximally dramatic. This kind of grit/heaviness ends up being a shortcut to feelings of gravitas and after a while it can ring hollow once everyone has adopted that affect.

author: BatMeckley
content:
These are two different things.
If you are doing meticulous need to be unbothered nerd shit, it’s great to have someone to keep the artist entertained. 

I would lose my mind, and my intern, if they kept interrupting a creative flow to yap. 

Again, (again again again), this business is 20% understanding gear, and 80% understanding people. You have to know your artists. Often, id even argue more often than not, it’s the fuckery and the messing around that often inspires the best ideas. We tend to be very bad at being creative with a gun to our head. As a producer, I’m trying to foster that safety and relaxation, while taking a Birds Eye view of the conversation listening for anything that I can go “wait! THAT was a lyric” or a riff or whatever. That’s always worked much better than me staring at someone going “hush. Write.”

Occasionally, like the old Peter Gabriel SO story, you have to lock the artist in the room and tell them they can’t come out until they’re done. But most of the time that just gets the job done, rather than the job done well.

author: Rollmottle
content: Some of my most creative thinking and best ideas come during wildly unfocused time. The same principle as passive listening -- you hear something totally different and it might be revealing in a way you can't access while actively listening. I think it's dangerous to try and impose rules around how somebody is most creatively fertile. It's different for everybody and may manifest in ways that aren't how they manifest for you. It's important to recognize whether it's truly them or is it actually you. You could certainly propose trying different approaches together to see what that sparks (more like Oblique Strategies), but best to be clear on what's driving what you're feeling lest you inadvertently kill the vibe or shut down a path.

author: bobby k
content:
Im by no means articulating anything against divergent thinking in fact it is the backbone of all art & creative problem solving, the mark of genius like ruairi was saying. 

Perhaps my original question has more to do with highlighting a lack of motivation or investment in the present moment, one that can so often stem from phone addiction? And banning phones or blocking reception is just kind of intense… 

A headspace I try to inject in myself is to pretend that any time I’m in a moment, it’s the last time I’ll ever get to do that thing. Whether it’s making a record or cooking a meal or sitting in traffic or having a beer with all of my favorite local discord friends tomorrow night.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
I've been melodyning vocals for a ten song album past couple weeks and feel like I've leveled up my chops significantly. I'm no Beckley, but browsing whats been previously shared here and trial and error has been the mechanism of growth for me.

I kinda had the note separation tool workflow down from work in other programs. I've been experimenting with the time tool and attack speed tool as well as formant shifting to mask when the tuning becomes more audible than I'd like. That's probably where I'd pinpoint the level up for me personally. That and trying to be more conscious about not relying too much on the graphical UI. Unless it's something that really calls for hard tuning I lean towards wanting it to feel invisible / natural. Im realizing more what parts of the note actually need to be more 'on' and which can be more 'off' or just left alone. That and letting notes naturally drift to become more sharp as they tail off. If I'm too heavy handed it starts to feel lifeless to me. I'm also appreciating more the nuance of how one might approach different genres or styles with melodyne. Its humbling how powerful the program really is.

There've been a few moments with the attack speed tool that have felt like magic curing some subtleties of the performances that bug me, but I don't feel super confident that I have a grasp on that one yet. I've been working in standalone and importing a REF mix. For some reason I feel more confident dealing with esses in protools with RX or clip gain than I do melodyne idk why. Some frustrations have been flipping back and forth between tracks when tuning multiple files feels real clunky. I might be missing something about how best to do that. I wish, like with RX monitor, you could hear the vocal through your mix chain when tuning (is that possible?). Being able to rename exported files would be nice too like in RX.

author: Deleted User
content:
I had this one particular vocal session where I was fucking up and all my comments were messing with the artist’s flow. So about an hour or two into the session, I got real with the artist and said “I feel like I’m being too much of a control-freak and my comments seem to be distracting you. Why don’t we take a break? When we come back, let’s forget about everything I mentioned earlier and see how things come out when you express freely. I have a feeling that it’s gonna turn out way better. I’m sorry, I think I got it your way” 

then after the break, the artist started nailing the takes. Not in the exact way I imagined, but in the best possible way that we were capable of THAT DAY. 

Since then, I decided to let go of control a bit more and let the artists do their thing as much as I can. I started developing ears for hearing what artists can work on before the session to get a better recording to my best of ability (if I get to know them before the sesh). I would only mention the simple things that can be improved with small adjustments short-term. That way the session can be more experimental and wild as opposed to fault-finding.

author: cian riordan

Distortion, compression, Eq, delays before/after, flanger/phaser, stereoizer. If I’m tweaking reverb in the production phase, I’m going ham on it to make sound like something interesting. author: Zach Hughes
content: I can't take credit for this framework (might have actually been in a conversations pod ep) but something I've adopted in my own production practice is the idea of convergence and divergence. If you are trying to converge on final guitar takes while your client is wanting to diverge and explore new creative ideas, then might be worth explicitly communicating 'this is where we're at and here's what we need to get done today' as lead producer before you begin tracking just so everyone knows. I'd be wary of stifling the exploration / play of your client, but maybe you could have them channel that into a notebook or voice memo in the back of the studio and you could schedule a time with the sole purpose of fucking around and exploring / playing with new ideas. Really just wanna make sure everyone knows when you're in 'convergence mode' and when you're in 'divergence mode' to avoid that frustration.

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s been my experience that the directors usually have no clue what they actually want. I had another brief where they wanted “super modern” “hits of today” where they’d ref’d a dua lipa song, gave them something that was so close it probably wouldn’t have cleared copyright, then they said “no, more like this” and gave me a song that was 8 years old (that i actually had the stems for) , used THE ACTUAL stems and they were like “we can’t use it those stomps sound like gunshots” when it was the EXACT TRACK that they’d ask me to reference. 

The corporate hustle is learning how to interpret what they say they want with what they actually mean is how they want it to feel, and then being prepared to have it go through a dozen not musician hands, with each person having to give notes to justify their job. It pays well but it is about the farthest thing from “being creative and making music” as it gets.

They are almost never on the bleeding edge of what’s cool, and that’s fine, you just need to go in knowing that.

author: Slow Hand
content:
There's no right way to go about sound selection, but ultimately you have to use your intuition and taste to judge if they're right for the record you're making. If the sounds don't seem to fit, then perhaps you need to ask yourself what effect it is that you're going for in the first place. Why are you trying to put *those* two sounds together? Decide if they get you close to that goal. If not, then simply find another sound. Not everything needs to work.

A lot of it comes down to intention and conviction. "Wrong" notes or sounds that are dramatically different can still be pulled off if you play them with confidence and panache. Records are full of sonic choices that stick out like a sore thumb, and we can make them sound coherent with conviction. What might sound abrasive and weird at first can easily become habituated and familiar with enough exposure.

I think almost any combination is valid. There are sound choices that are conventional and there are choices that go against the grain. Every unconventional choice is an opportunity to create a new genre or to create a new mood. It can be a matter of mindset. If you can free yourself from the need to do the "right" thing then the creativity to play with unusual combinations will come a lot easier.

Of course, this is all hard to discuss without hearing examples. If you can give us more examples of what you're dealing with perhaps we can be more specific.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I will say I don't think it's all about their vision or when they want to pivot. It's a bit more nuanced. 

If you are truly a producer collaborator (as opposed to a hired gun engineer or musician), it's about trying all the ideas and collectively deciding what's best. But remember YOU are the one who holds the keys to the execution of the artist's ideas. You can have ideas and try them yourself, but if the artist has ideas, it's still YOU that has to execute them (because presumably they're not a producer like you). 

So you're actually building a big creative trust by helping the artist try stuff. If you can execute ideas that the artist can't quite articulate or do themselves, you gain a credibility where you can both listen and then say "Ah, I see what you mean. I think this other version is best."

author: Slow Hand
content:
Any polyphonic subtractive synth should be able to get you there. There's nothing so unique about the sound that you'd need a specific synth model. The characteristic sound of this patch is a saturated LPF with an ADSR filter sweep. It may actually be a monophonic synth with a second oscillator tuned to +7 and blended in at a lower volume. It doesn't sound like they're playing chords, so much as stacked oscillators.

As others mentioned, a Prophet is a good place to start, but it's not going to get you that heavy-grit saturation by itself that we hear on this record. Prophets don't get that dirty on their own. Maybe the Prophet X's with DSP effects will. I haven't used them.

Something like a Moog synth is going to lean heavier into the saturation capabilities. That record feels much more like a Moog filter. A Moog Matriarch is the first thing I'd reach for if it were available to use.

That said, you've probably got enough saturation boxes lying around that you can approximate that grit. But it's a very Moog-y saturation sound.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you know your way around a synthesizer, Massive X and Serum 2 are both heavy hitters that cover all of my bases. 

Sonically, Massive X has a "warmer" voicing and has all of NI's amazing effect algorithms built into it. Everything sounds incredible and is dripping with character. It's absurdly capable, but the interface may be overwhelming at first. It can be a lot to get oriented on. It's impossible for this thing to sound "cold". The preset library is less bass music/EDM and more balanced. NI offers a lot of genre-themed expansions. If you like programming sequenced/heavily automated one-button patches Massive X is king.

Serum is on the "cold" side, but just as capable of "warmer" sounds. The sonics and DSP are clear as a bell. Stellar. It's more intuitive to program and the feature set is an embarrassment of riches. It's absurd how much functionality Steve and team crammed into it. Absolutely absurd. If you want to do EDM and bass music, it's the king and it's preset library leans towards that. I still cannot believe that they *gave* it away to Serum 1 users.

Both excel at cinematic and over the top. If you're looking for the "classic" sound, I'd lean Massive X.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
Im pretty much always messing with the length of kick, snare and hat trying to get them to fit in the grove better, you can make some unlikely pairs work when you do this.

Also always messing with the order in which transients are hitting on downbeats, nudging certain drums slightly before or after others can make things mesh together real nice. Typically the higher pitched/attacky things like hi hats come earlier than the sub kicks for example but experiment with it and see what sounds good. A song where this is really obvious is say it right by nelly furtado, listen to the way the layers are stacked on the downbeats of the chorus. Side note, when you're doing this, think of everything with a transient on that downbeat as a percussion instrument.

author: wilhelmjosephk
content: I love this sound and a lot of the other stuff that Jockstrap's come up with, and while this is a bit of a non-answer, I think the key is that these sounds are easier to arrive at than they are to aim for. I think a lot of what Taylor Skye is doing is taking sounds and then warping them/distorting them to shit using all of the "wrong" methods, and then just judging what comes out and deciding if it should be kept. I think there's a good hint of this in the lead sound at the start, where it's really out of rhythm and grainy, some notes seem to sort of "break" which reminds me of the results you get when you try to formant shift a verbed-out or polyphonic sound with little alterboy, or even abusing izotope RX on something that doesn't really need it (also, the RX de-reverb can do wild things to a sound you've put reverb on higher in the chain). Logic, which is what he uses, also has a lesser known formant shift that you can only get to by turning on flex pitch then adjusting in the side info bar, which can really take sounds into space. I haven't done this with melodyne, but I imagine there are some similar features.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yup! Massive was my go-to for years prior to Massive X.

The biggest change for me is that the raw oscillators sound far better. The original Massive had a lot of aliasing that could make it sound hazy and flat. Switching over to Massive X it is crystal clear and even buzzy saw waves feel warm, pure, and tactile.

It has extremely flexible modulation capabilities that I find to be very musical as well as some very comprehensive ADSHR envelopes. It also has four different keyboard tracking curves that you can assign and tweak, which is very important when fine-tuning your patch to make sure that it sounds even across the entire range of keys.

It has a lot of musical sounding filters that can inject a ton of vibe, or be completely neutral. The *noise* section is robust and very flexible. I use it a lot.

Finally, it has a great-sounding set of internal effects (delay, chorus, saturation, verb, etc) that can be placed anywhere inside of the routing diagram. It's always a bummer when the on-board effects aren't very inspiring. But NI has a strong catalog of well-designed dsp to draw on and integrate into their products, so it's turned out great.

Overall, it's a very robust and well-rounded synthesizer that also does a lot of things extremely well. It can be super clean (like Serum) but also get very dirty, which I appreciate in a synth.

The only thing I don't like is that the preset browser kind of sucks. I prefer the original Massive's browser. NI is well aware and they have been overhauling it and slowly adding new features, so I trust in time this will be made better.

author: LAPhill
content:
Oooh I have a theory here, about cultural values. Audiences in the 1800s, for instance, could go to a symphonic concert and recognize sonata form, key centers, etc. There was an appreciation for the form of the music and the virtuosity of the player first and foremost. Acknowledgement of skill. Making things seem effortless was the ideal.

Contemporary listeners seem to connect more with the struggle. They want to hear the grit in the vocal, the player at the edge of their ability (whatever it may be) holding on for dear life. The mix at the edge of distortion. In that breaking point, there is a lot of beauty and emotion that would have traditionally been considered bad form. Uncouth, even!

author: Deleted User
content:
Learn what different carrier to modulator ratios sound like by messing with them only using sine waves.  and then feel out what it feels like feedback carrier and/or the modulator. And then you can introduce envelopes to create shapes with them. 

Tool wise- I would start with FM8, it’s pretty much DX7 but without the limitations of routing configuration like it does in Arturia DX7. And then you can learn with arturia DX7 in conjunction with how the different configuration work. +FM8 has patch morphing function which can be VERY useful when it comes to FM sounds. Another cool thing about FM8 is that it shows you all of the sidebands. 

From here, it’s all experimentation

That’s really all you need, FM looks intimidating but it’s really not that difficult. 


linear FM is essentially really fast vibrato. Non linear FM is a fast trill between the two frequencies. AM is essentially fast *unipolar* tremolo, RM is fast *bipolar: meaning it shifts polarity too* tremolo. they all create sonic characters by creating sidebands. 

one thing to keep in mind is most FM synths are actually not FM. it’s actually imitated by doing phase modulation- but results are almost identical. except in actual FM, you get more of the carrier frequency. So FM with a high-pass filtered modulator is essentially the same as PM with a low pass filtered modulator


run down on difference in sidebands between the most common audio-rate modulated synthesis:

FM/PM creates equally spaced sidebands

RM only produces sidebands (carrier frequency + modulator frequency & carrier frequency- modulator frequency)

AM is carrier with side bands of c+m and c-m

I’d give that a shot (the aforementioned mutt lang one note at a time chord theory, which supposedly has been overblown, though I’ve heard guys like MUSE have explored it later on) before you go too haywire looking at dramatic eq moves or what not.

author: Slow Hand
content:
*Massive X* came out a few years ago and immediately became my main workhorse/swiss army synth.

It's extremely well rounded, deep, flexible, sounds *impeccable*, and has a wealth of well curated NI effects built in that make it a one-stop shop.

It's probably overkill for most people and I'm nowhere near close to squeezing all of the juice that it has to offer. But it's so comprehensive that I immediately stopped using 80% of my synths. At this point the only other synth I use is NI *Razor*, which is it's own distinct animal.

I could spend the rest of my life learning to master *Massive X*, and I feel confident that it's a worthy pursuit. It's allowed me to focus on mastering a single instrument. I've stopped being 20% good at several synths and am now deeply familiar with a single tool. I'm very pleased with it.

Unfortunately it randomly does the following:
*reads notes in the wrong octave
*plays back notes in the wrong octave
*shaves off all the high end

*adds a weird glitch that sounds like a bad edit in the rendered file
*says it can't authorize the plugin

So I'm constantly shifting between classic and modern modes, and switching the input type which sometime corrects some of these things. Again, often seemingly at random.

If that doesn’t click, separate the two. Don’t sound design while starting a track. Set aside dedicated time to make patches, which can still inspire songs. Ultimately, even the best sounds do not matter if the arrangement and melodies are not strong.

author: peterlabberton
content: I’ve done this a few different ways as well—once, both songs were mixed in the same session, and then bounced separately for mastering. (FWIW, that Pro Tools session became an absolute nightmare—wouldn’t necessarily recommend this method unless there is some reason to do so. In this case we had effects/elements from the first song pop up later on in the second song.) I left blank space in the second song’s bounce so they could be lined up perfectly. Other times I’ve taken a stereo bounce of one song and dropped it into the mix session for the other just to mock things up as we go. What happens on the mastering side I am less familiar with… but if it’s something specific we’re after I’ll usually send along a reference of the exact timing/fade/etc. for them to match.

author: Slow Hand
content:
As a practical example of when not being in phase is the right move:

Jon Castelli did a live mix on Twitch on Wednesday that included live drums. He identified that one of the snare mics sounded fuller when he inverted the polarity and proceeded to mix with that. 

Later in that session when it came time for notes, the producer (who was present in the room) asked why the snare had lost a certain thin and "woody" character that they liked. Jon reverted the snare mic to it's original polarity and the producer went "Ahh! There it is."

So the takeaway here is that while drums usually *do* sing the best and hit the hardest when they're all working in phase with one another, sometimes the creative intention overrides the need to align them in a way that makes them most "full".

As you say: If it sounds good, it is good.

author: LAPhill
content:
IME it depends a lot on who the players are. There are certain people I would call to play parts more or less as written, and others whose whole vibe is based off of experimentation. Both have their place for sure.

One thing you keyed in on that is really crucial is the "space" you ask them to fill. Even something as simple as "ad lib between vocal lines" tells the player a lot about where they need to fit in, while still giving them a lot of freedom to bring their thing to the production. 

Certainly a place for all of these approaches, and the more you know and trust the musicians around you, the easier it becomes to envision where it might go (and leave room for pleasant surprises).

author: Slow Hand
content:
I agree with @BatMeckley's approach on this. Have them execute your vision, and then once you have it let them go wild and swing big. Try something new.

It's up to either the artist or you, as the producer, to have a vision for what the song is, where it's going, and what it needs. One of you have to have a roadmap. *Someone* needs to have the vision. To be the leader. To steer the ship.

If the vision is not clear then perhaps the song itself needs to be refined some more until it has a strong identity. That will be your north star for creative decisions. 

If you can convey the essence of the song to your players, the emotion behind it, then they can interpret that feeling in a way that is uniquely them without the need for you to dictate their parts. If you can give them an emotion and maybe some general contour of what you're hearing then they can fill in the spaces and bring their own qualities.

As producer, part of your job is curating the talent that you recruit to realize your vision. If you know what the song needs you can confidently pick a player with complimentary sensibilities. If you can pick the right person then very often most of the work is done by virtue of them being aligned with the song. Each of their contributions and ideas are likely to be excellent.

----

author: gatewoodsensei

I’m not sure if this’ll help, but I tend to go with whatever hits me at the time. If it’s a melody, I’ll sing it, mumble words, and allow the music to form around that idea. If it’s lyrics, then i grab a guitar or sit in front of the keyboard and play the accompaniment. Or if I’m in front of my computer, and melody line hits, I’ll play the melody, or chords and allow it to loop while I write. So I don’t necessarily balance, because to me that means I’m shutting part of my creativity off i order to allow the other part to flow, and more often than not, that kills the creative flow. 

So don’t try to balance anything. Whatever you feel, go with that and allow your creativity to flow.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Unless you really know what you want, writing and arranging *into* OTT from the beginning seems like a mistake because it will severely distort your ability to tell what moves you're making.

You're basically marrying yourself to the OTT sound up front if you start with it on, because If you try to dial it back later on in the process you're going to reveal all of the weird moves that you made to compensate for OTT's sound.

In general, I find OTT works best on individual instruments, and not on groups, except in extreme circumstances. If you want the OTT sound I'd advise you to apply it on individual tracks, rather than on your entire mix buss.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Agreed. If that's what the client wants, then do it - unless they say that they've specifically hired you for your progressive taste.

That said, a good director will have given Rob guidance on the tone that they want in the video and hopefully the client's brand is defined enough that we can know what would be appropriate and what would not be appropriate.

What is the client trying to project with their branding? Are they cool? Classy? Expensive? Creative? Reliable? Simple?

In the case of the U.N. they're international, serious, responsible, far seeing, and dignified. Those are the targets I would be thinking about.

author: Rollmottle
content: As others have said, recreating a beat you like is the school you need to go to. One of my favorite beats of all time is Fleetwood Mac's "Hypnotized" which is a swingy, triplet unchanging thing that is effectively a drum loop through the song, except Mick Fleetwood plays it. I recreated it using a sample pack of Mick Fleetwood's and turned it into a song after serious finagling, especially in the context of grid music. The insight into accent, velocity, swing, where in the grid things hit (or don't), which specific hits matter and how dropping just one or two key hits in a repetitive pattern can shift the groove entirely. It also tests your chops for figuring out choke groups, how to make closed and open hi hats sound "real" (if that's your goal) so on and so forth. I also love recreating a beat as a way in when musical inspiration may be lacking.

I am grateful that I only ever had to splice tape in school and that I don't need a six-seven figure analog studio and the Wrecking Crew to make a track

author: Rollmottle
content:
I think this is where it starts getting tricky and starts to dip into territory @Zakhiggins was touching on. Is there an objective measure of what good production is? 

Tons and tons of dub and reggae from the 70s and 80s would be what I would consider not necessarily great production -- from a technical standpoint -- but a lot of those shortcomings (noise, grit, distortion, etc.) don't get in the way of the end product because the sum total well surpasses any production shortcomings. Most of the punk, post-punk and hardcore stuff I listened to in the 90s would also fall well below a bar most would consider “well produced” but the music transcends any of that for me. 

So…by my measure, all of these recordings I mentioned ARE well-produced by nature of them being good to me and still “adding up” so to speak. By somebody else's measure, they may not be because they don’t meet some threshold -- be it technical, artistic, whatever -- of what they consider well-produced.

content:
I do this a lot!

In Ableton, you have soooo many options. Most often I put the sample on an Ableton Simpler and am able to slice / pitch / etc really fluidly — record that, and then edit by hand. This is my workflow for 90% of vocal chops. If it’s really simple I’ll do it by hand but I find I get more musical results if I can “play” the chop. 

There’s also Buffer Shuffler and Beat Repeat in Ableton which can be fun and unpredictable. 

The Glitch Machines plugins are also really nice if you’re going for something a bit crazy (two of them are free and very good). I don’t fully understand them yet so I just throw them on when I want something wacky to happen. 

And I’ll also second stutter edit — very fun for “playing” chops live too, and editing presets isn’t too hard either.

author: Deleted User
content:
All of these methods suggested will yield in different results. 

Resonators are made from delay using feedback to create tones. So you may need to resample to kill sustains - or not if you want it to have lengthiness. If you are going for SOPHIE kind of sound then you'd probably keep the feedback. 

Booms (filter resonance) are similar mechanisms but less tonal unless you turn up the feedback a lot more - it will certainly be more natural sounding as opposed to comb-filtery sound. 

Layering will give more focused pitch while maintaining the integrity of the layered sample sound, you would probably have the most control this way. 

Vocoder will have inherently baked sound because of the synthesis mechanism, it can be desirable or not depending on the scenario. 

With sampler looping, you will get grainier tail - dialing in the decay is necessary if you want the sound to be percussive because it will just continue sustaining. You can create pads this way too!

content:
That makes sense! 

To me being outside the studio is much more about finding the vision, than being able to execute it. I don’t care if my kick is 15db too loud and everything is distorted to hell. If there’s a vibe that’s inspiring that’s all that matters. Once the vision is clear it’s usually easy to reign it in and start making sense of thing once you get back into the studio, because now the goal is clear. author: Slow Hand
content:
I haven't done a deep-dive on *Autotune Real Time*'s algorithm, but my guess is that it would be a delay-line style pitch shifter because of it's need to process in real time.

Those types of pitch shifters are just fancy arrays of that pitch-rising/pitch-falling effect that you can get on a high-feedback delay unit by modulating the delay time. So it follows that they're going to have to delay the signal by *a little bit* in order to allow some audio into the buffer.

author: ALXCPH
content: HiQ is an interpolation algorithm that lets you pitch or src an audio file with less distortion than with out. What do you not like about it? Gotta be honest I’ve never actually messed with that setting.

author: austenballard
content: My understanding is that HiQ reduces distortion if you're using complex or pro to change the pitch, but otherwise all it does is reduce audio quality by resampling. It's the  'complex modes are never neutral' disclaimer they put in the manual.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Yeah that makes sense, it has to interpolate the audio, so if you have it off it doesn’t need to touch the audio, so there is no difference. But as soon as you are stretching the audio I would turn it on to get the least distortion possible. Like he mentions just turn of warp when it’s not needed, and on when it is, that way you don’t have to think about it. 

What I was curious about was why you would have HiQ turned of while stretching or pitching something.

author: ALXCPH
content: As soon as any audio is manipulated you fidelity is lessened, but the HiQ just makes it less distorted

author: austenballard
content:
> What I was curious about was why you would have HiQ turned of while stretching or pitching something.

Because I still have trust issues from Ableton 9 SRC. 

I use HiQ when pitch shifting because apparently that's what it's for, but (from what little I can actually understand of Zplane's documentation) stretching is a different operation from pitch shifting. So HiQ stays off.

author: ALXCPH
content: Maybe the extra distortion is desirable and masks some artefacts

author: austenballard
content:
It's not a make or break issue at all really... I think this conversation got dragged a bit into the weeds. Anyway, I went back and fact-checked myself for my, and anyone else's, benefit:

- It's Tones mode that roughly works like manual stretching. Emphasis on *roughly*

- HiQ is only intended to reduce artifacts from SRC or pitch-shifting. It does have an effect on audio quality and doesn't need to be on if you're not doing one of those two things. Stretching in Complex or Complex Pro does not need HiQ to be on.

- It's unclear whether the Infinitewave SRC measurements for Ableton apply to the SRC algorithm used for warping.

On the other point, we don't need to know the nuts and bolts, but it would be nice to unambiguously know when something is degrading sound quality in Ableton's case, or behaving differently in different versions of the 'same' software in Celemony's case.

author: jonmatteson
content: I would definitely recommend having hi q on if you are doing any time stretching or pitch shifting. The cumulative effect of it is very noticeable in my experience.

author: austenballard
content: per the manual, HiQ doesn't affect time stretching, only SRC and pitch shifting

author: ALXCPH
content: I think it does actually. HiQ from what I understand just interpolates the signal. So when you are stretching it, it upsamples the audio to have more sample points for more accurate stretching and then Downsamples it to the original again for playback so you get less distortion after the fact. At least it’s how my brain understands it.

author: austenballard
content:
I don't know if there's adequate information for either of us to know if we're 'right'.

Where things are really unclear is whether this applies in Complex and Complex Pro modes. Those are licensed Zplane Elastique algorithms which, according to the product page, is for both "time stretching & pitch shifting"

https://licensing.zplane.de/technology#elastique

author: austenballard
content:
There's pretty extensive documentation of Zplane Elastique, which I did attempt to read once upon a time:

https://licensing.zplane.de/uploads/SDK/ELASTIQUE-PRO/V3/manual/elastique_pro_v3_sdk_documentation.pdf

as far as I can make out, the pitch shifting and time stretching functions are unrelated operations, and pitch shifting uses resampling, but time stretching does not.

I'm also a dummy, though, and a lot of what's in this document is waaaay above my head

author: JakeTB
content:
Method: Recorded vocal at 192kHz into Pro Tools. Exported via Shift+CMD+K at 192kHz and again at 48kHz. Vocals were both imported into Melodyne application in monophonic mode. Administered time stretching (both lengthened and shortened) via the time tool. Also administered pitch shifting via pitch tool and checked detection of tuning via correct pitch macro. After exporting these, they were reimported to see if detection had changed.

Objective Results:
-Upon import, vocal tempo detection was different. (One detected in 5/4, the other in 3/4, at drastically different tempos).
-For short notes, when using the time tool to stretch, there were audible differences in results.
-For long notes, when using the time tool to shorten, there was significantly less audible difference (subjectively: no difference)
-For pitch detection, the algorithm detected pitch differently both audibly and visually.

Subjective Opinions:
-Time stretching yielded reduced artifacts in extreme settings when done at 192kHz. It did not eliminate all artifacts, but did reduce them.
-When time stretching in a more nuanced way, the differences in artifacts were negligible.
-When adjusting pitch manually, there was no audible difference in the quality of the pitch shifting at different sample rates. (For this test, everything was shifted up half an octave before any adjustments made)
-When detecting pitch, both behaved quite differently. This was partially due to detection of select blobs being different at either sample rate. (This was most surprising to me of all the results)
-When blobs were adjusted to match as closely as possible by hand, the tuning seemed to behave identically, including locations and levels of artifacts. (My gut says they “felt” different but that is most likely either placebo or the slight differences in true blob locations)

author: austenballard
content: Your observation on no audible difference for pitch shifting, yeah I couldn't *hear* the difference either but I also did this on my MacBook Air listening through system output 🙃  but measurement suggests there is a difference and it might be significant if you're combining dramatic pitch, time, formant, god knows what else shifting

content: And better/more modern effects - the vibrato is based off the shallow water pedal and can easily give you cassette sounding wobble or nice movement that people usually do in like rc20 - but because I do it in the audio samples instead of just the incoming buffer you have a lot more freedom (and It has different vibrato movement per voice)

author: Skyler Young
content: The reverse effect I’m obsessed with - it syncs to your bpm and can make really cool pumping sounds or intresting swelling chords that would typically take a number of steps to do otherwise

author: Skyler Young
content: The tone shift effect is something that I was thinking about for a long time - it manipulates which samples you access for each note played. For example you shift it +12 and play C1 it will take the sample from C0 and play it at double speed - changing the character of the sound sometimes drastically. If the range knob is at 50% and shift is at 0 and you play C0 it will use the sample from G0 (because it’s 50% the distance from C0) and if you play C2 it will use the sample from G1 - also has interesting effects on the sound. I still haven’t figured out the best way of explaining this function but I find it really usable and I’ve never seen sometime implement it before.

author: LAPhill
content: To further dig in on the pre delay time - It also affects the perception of how far into the room the source is. If you have a long predelay, it creates the effect that your source is close to you, in a large space. Conversely, no prelay will position your source farther into the room, where the reverb and direct signal hit your ear concurrently. (These effects work in tandem with wet/dry mix to further accentuate the positioning)

author: chris_donlin
content: Does anyone have a quick way to take a melodic riff on guitar/keys/etc and have each note play in reverse? I dont want the whole clip to just play backwards. I want the melody the same. Slice to new midi track in ableton almost gets me there but i cant reverse the samples within each sampler... or can i?

author: ! Andy !
content: Slice each note you want to reverse in the audio file & hit r

author: Slow Hand
content:
I don't think *slice to MIDI* is the way here. It will become tedious if you have rests in between notes.

Imagine that you have a quarter note followed by a quarter note rest in your melody. If you *slice to MIDI* it will slice that sequence into a half-note length clip. If you then reverse that clip the rest will play *first*, followed by the reversed quarter note.

author: Slow Hand
content: Doing it manually is probably the safest bet until someone writes a Max patch to automate it. Print to audio, slice at the note start and end, and then hit *R* to reverse the desired notes.

author: Zack Hames

So, I think it’s superbly underrated. Especially the new Akai MPC lives, one, etc series.

I use it as a drum machine/sampler/sequencer for all of my hardware synths. It’s the brain and controller for everything.

But you can also use it completely on its own, you can put any sample all the way across a keyboard/pads to the correct pitch automatically. 

There are built in AIR effects. You can time stretch, etc do whatever with samples. 

Load up any drum samples and go to town. 

It also has some built in instruments / synths, but I rarely use those. 

It’s essentially a portable DAW as far as music production. I prefer it to computer by far for producing / writing with samples and synths

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
To stick with a song I made, MIRROR, I had the lead say anxieties earlier in the song in the middle, then later add those full lines as BGs that almost swirl around the last hooks lead. The lead is performing a part that’s trying to overcome anxieties, and the BGs are saying full lines with the anxieties from before.

Panning was essential to create the effect of the anxieties around the lead, but I found that if I introduced them as panned BGs they were hard to make out behind the lead.

Because of this, knowing when to make a moment earlier in the song to spotlight what would later be panned made those lines more intelligible once they were in the BG to the sides, because the listeners brain recognized it from an earlier section.

Does that make sense? I can struggle to explain what I’m doing in practice and this is my attempt, so my bad if it sounds like gobrish

author: Slow Hand
content:
Oh I certainly feel that. 

I'll often find myself making records that start to fall into three or four different buckets (ex: heavy stuff, singer songwriter, experimental, etc...). I start grouping together the tracks that feel complimentary and then when I have enough they'll start to suggest a direction for an album, at which point I'll focus on that larger project until it's complete.

Then I jump back into the songs in the remaining buckets and use them as the jumping off point for the next release. That's one way to do it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
It sounds like it may be a simple haas-effect spread by delaying one side by a few ms. 

That would be easy enough to modulate with a stereo delay: Keep one channel at 0 ms and then automate the opposite channel in the range of 0-60ms

I also have let go of my habit of watching endless tutorials before starting a session. I especially dislike going down the rabbit hole of  those "50 advanced production tricks to level up your sound" videos. It's like why am I watching this instead of creating some actual music first?

yes, creating a bank of samples and sounds beforehand is the way to go. 
On those days, I'll just spend my time doing sound design and exploring sounds that fit the genre. 

I've realised that scheduling and managing time well is important, even in music.

Btw, did you talk about the vibe and atmosphere of the track in advance with your clients in order to do better sound selection for the style they wanted to go for?

author: sethearnest
content:
I’ve been doing this a lot with a buddy. We house everything in DB as the “master” session then each backup to our own backup systems. 

One thing we’ve noticed is that PT seems less happy working out of DB on our rigs — I’m going to experiment with “pausing sync” in DB next time we get into a heavy session as we’re actually working to see if that helps. 

But generally has worked great aside from a slight performance dip (which doesn’t seem to affect some other people as much, so maybe it’s just our own rigs’ issues). And general best practices of Save-As’ing often have proven important as we’re both working on various things so we’re not messing up each other’s work/sessions.
